results.title: Daddy long legs
results.creator_credit: Jean Negulesco, Samuel G. Engel and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A remake of the 1931 film, but greatly expanded to allow for the dancing of Fred Astaire and Leslie Caron. It is the story of a French orphan whose schooling is sponsored by an American millionaire on the stipulation that she will never know his identity. His secretary (Thelma Ritter) is so touched by her letters of gratitude, delivered by the school, that she persuades him to visit. He is enchanted by the elegant, lovely girl and falls in love with her - and she with him, without knowing who he is. The film contains a wide range of music including a jazz piece with drums by Astaire, a ballet danced by Caron, several dream sequences with Astaire imagining himself as a playboy and a rich cowboy, and Johnny Mercer’s memorable song Something’s Gotta Give.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jean Negulesco, Samuel G. Engel and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation

results.title: Dad, I made it!
results.creator_credit: Figen Hasimoglu, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A promise to her father lead Figen Hasimoglu from her homeland of Turkey to Australia, in search of a better life and a chance for a good education.

results.title: Dad and Dave: on our selection
results.creator_credit: George Whaley, Bruce Davey, Anthony Buckley, AFFC, Anthony Buckley Productions and ICON
results.brief_description: Steele Rudd’s classic Dad and Dave stories represent what is both noble and comic in colonial society. The Rudd’s are a loud, unconventional farming family, ekeing out a living in the harsh conditions of the bush with little respect for authority. Stereotypical “fair dinkum Aussies”, Dad’s blustering and Ma’s stoicism hold the family together. This film features the talents of an all-star cast including Leo McKern, Dame Joan Sutherland, Geoffrey Rush, Ray Barrett, Nicholas Eadie, Noah Taylor and Barry Otto, with songs and music by Peter Best.

results.title: Dad and Dave come to town
results.brief_description: The third film in Cinesound’s ‘Dad and Dave’ series, this film had virtually nothing in common with the Steele Rudd stories and instead was based upon one of Ken Hall’s favourite comic formulae of the ‘fish out of water’. The Rudd family are taken from their usual rural haunts to the city when Dad unexpectedly inherits a women’s fashion emporium. Cast includes Bert Bailey, Shirley Ann Richards, Peter Finch, Fred MacDonald, Billy Rayes, Alec Kellaway, Sidney Wheeler, Connie Martyn, Ossie Wenban, Valerie Scanlan, Muriel Flood, Leila Steppe, Marshall Crosby, Cecil Perry, Billy Stewart, Marie D’Alton and Leslie Victor.

results.title: Dad's tools
results.creator_credit: Fred Atwell, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: There is a lot to do after a bushfire but Fred Atwell wants more than anything to find his dad’s cherished homemade tools. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with Latrobe City and Arts Victoria.

results.title: Dad's house, mum's house
results.brief_description: Shared custody, co-parenting, share-parenting…it goes by different names. The children may move back and forth between parents, or one parent may retain day-to-day care…its form varies from family to family. Joint custody allows both parents to participate in major decisions affecting their child’s health, education and welfare.
results.description: Shared custody, co-parenting, share-parenting…it goes by different names. Joint custody allows both parents to participate in major decisions affecting their child’s health, education and welfare.

results.title: Dad's goanna
results.brief_description:
One of two stories in MAP about the stuffed animal displays in the Murtoa Museum. In this short doco, Meryl Duder talks about her life in Murtoa as a young girl of 10, relating the tale of “dad’s goanna” and how it ended up preserved in Mr Hill’s house in Murtoa in a room full of many other stuffed animals. Years later, on returning to Murtoa with her daughter and to the Murtoa Museum, Meryl was delighted to be able to point out and say “there’s dad’s goanna”.
Filmed by Malcolm McKinnon and made with the assistance of Murtoa Historical Society and Murtoa Lions Club.
The James Hill Bird Collection is held by the Lions Club of Murtoa under a special scientific license.

results.title: Dad's Girl/Common Ground
results.creator_credit: Martin Daley, Judy Menczel, Pamela Williams and Ron Saunders
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Breakthrough series”.
In “Dad’s Girl” we meet Janea who lives with her mother and still misses her father years after the divorce. She discusses the effect of her parents’ divorce on her life. In “Common Ground”, Sean’s experience of his parents’ divorce and his new step-father are shown along with the changes he makes to adapt to his new family situation.

results.title: Dad's army: Turkey dinner. Ring dem bells. When you've got to go
results.brief_description: Popular comic English television program “Dad’s army”, which ran for nine years, is about numerous men that comprise the local division of the Home Guard in the seaside town of Walmington-on-Sea during World War 2. The men are an eccentric lot who range in age from the very young to the decidedly doddery. In each episode the group muddle their way through a different situation in their own idiosyncratic way. Episodes include: “Turkey dinner” (30 mins, 1974) When Corporal Jones is left holding a dead turkey after the platoon’s drunken night-watch, Mainwaring decides to treat the town’s senior citizens to a feast. “Ring dem bells” (30 mins, 1975) Mainwaring is not pleased when his platoon is chosen to play Nazis in an Army film and Pike is selected to play a German officer. “When you’ve got to go” (1975, 30 mins) Despite his bad chest, sinuses and weak ankles, Pike is passed A1 on his medical.

results.title: Dad's army: Is there honey still for tea? Come in your time is up. High Finance
results.brief_description: Popular comic English television program “Dad’s army”, which ran for nine years, is about numerous men that comprise the local division of the Home Guard in the seaside town of Walmington-on-Sea during World War 2. The men are an eccentric lot who range in age from the very young to the decidedly doddery. In each episode the group muddle their way through a different situation in their own idiosyncratic way. Episodes include: “Is there honey still for tea?” (1975, 30 mins) Private Godfrey’s cottage is condemned to be bulldozed because a new airstrip is to be built. “Come in your time is up” (1975, 31 mins) Mainwaring’s platoon discovers a German crew in a dinghy on a lake and endeavour to bring them to shore. “High finance” (1975, 31 mins) Mainwaring decides that Jones’ bank account has been in the red too long.
